notes: Panel-first quoting. Never quote whole car unless user explicitly asks.
Always show low–high with add-ons called out as line items.

extra_prep.explain: Heavily faded/peeling/rough surfaces; charge labor+materials per hour

sealer_rule.apply_to: overall jobs always; panel jobs only when checkerboard/multiple substrates

rust_repair.notes: Grinding/fill vs cut/weld; can get expensive

rules: If extra_prep hours > 0, add labor_per_hour * hours plus materials_paint_per_hour * hours.
If bodywork chosen, add body labor time from estimator and materials_body_per_hour * hours.

warranty.panel_jobs: follows paint system chosen for that panel; prorated

conditions: Excludes non-like items (e.g., touch-up only vs refinish)

sales_language.sanding: We sand so the new paint sticks to the old. Better adhesion, smoother finish.
sales_language.sealer: Sealer evens the surface so it doesn’t look like a checkerboard. Cleaner color, better coverage.
sales_language.upgrade_to_bcc: Basecoat-clear gives deeper gloss and longer life. If you care about look and resale, this is it.
sales_language.warranty_pitch: We stand behind the work. All warranties are prorated and documented — no games.
sales_language.fleet_positioning: We price fair and fast. Volume and repeat work get priority scheduling and consistent rates.

guardrails: Never quote a full-vehicle repaint unless the customer explicitly requests 'full paint' or multiple panels exceed 70% of the car.
If user mentions single area (e.g., 'rear door'), scope only that panel + any required blends.
Always itemize: panel price, bodywork, extra prep hours, blends, pearls, sealer, oversize, tax (if applicable).
Always ask for 3–5 photos and VIN if unclear.
intake_questions: Which panel(s) are damaged or getting painted?
Any dents, rust, or peeling clear?
